How measured (data sources, definitions, segmentation, QA): Metrics were pulled from the ticketing system (e.g., Zendesk/ServiceNow-equivalent) and validated against a lightweight BI extract (scheduled export to spreadsheets + a simple dashboard view). **SLA attainment** was defined as % of tickets resolved (or first-response, depending on the SLA policy) within the agreed target for the ticket’s priority; we reported both **business-hours SLA** and **24/7** where relevant, and excluded tickets in a paused/waiting-on-customer state per policy. **TTFR** started at ticket create time (or first inbound customer message for reopened threads) and stopped at the first human agent response; we segmented by channel (email/web/chat) and priority (P1/P2 vs the rest) to avoid averages masking hot queues. **Backlog aging** was % of open tickets older than a threshold (e.g., >7 days) using current age at report time; we also tracked aging bands (0–2, 3–7, 8–14, 15+ days). QA checks included weekly spot-audits of priority tagging, sampling tickets around SLA breaches to confirm clock rules (business hours/pauses), and reconciling ticket counts between the source system and the export to catch filtering/duplication issues.
